"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since an inscribed angle is half of a central angle that subtends the same arc, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle BOC = 2A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle BOC' = \angle COB' = 180° - 2A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (from the straight line), "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\angle CBO = \angle BCO = 90° - A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (from the isosceles triangle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle BOC"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"), and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC = 2r \sin A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" (from a circle chord). "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Using the law of sines on "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\triangle BOA'"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gives "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"OA' = \frac{r \cos A}{\cos (B - C)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BA' = \frac{r \sin 2C}{\cos(B - C)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Similarly, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"OB' = \frac{r \cos B}{\cos (A - C)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"OC' = \frac{r \cos C}{\cos (A - B)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"CA' = \frac{r \sin 2B}{\cos(B - C)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"CB' = \frac{r \sin 2A}{\cos(A - C)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AB' = \frac{r \sin 2C}{\cos(A - C)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"AC' = \frac{r \sin 2B}{\cos(A - B)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"BC' = \frac{r \sin 2A}{\cos(A - B)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the radius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of an incircle is the quotient of the area of its triangle and the semiperimeter of its triangle, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r_1 = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \cdot r \cdot \frac{r\sin 2B}{\cos(A - B)} \cdot \sin(90° - C)}{\frac{1}{2}(r + \frac{r\sin 2B}{\cos(A - B)} + \frac{r\cos C}{\cos(A - B)})} = \frac{r \cos A \cos B \cos C}{\cos A \sin A + \cos A \cos B}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similarly:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the radius "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"R"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" of an excircle is the quotient of the area of its triangle and the difference of the semiperimeter of its triangle and the side it is tangent to, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"R_1 = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \cdot 2r \sin B \cdot (r + \frac{r \cos C}{\cos (A - B)}) \cdot \sin(90° - B)}{\frac{1}{2}(2r \sin B + r + \frac{r \cos C}{\cos (A - B)} + \frac{r \sin 2B}{\cos (A - B)}) - \frac{r \sin 2B}{\cos (A - B)}} = \frac{2r\sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos B \cos C}{2 \sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos B  + \sin A \sin B \cos A \cos B   -  \sin B \cos A \cos B \cos C - \sin B \cos A \cos^2 B}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similarly:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"R_3 = \frac{2r\sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos B \cos C}{2 \sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos C  + \sin A \sin C \cos A \cos C   -  \sin A \cos A \cos B \cos C - \sin A \cos C \cos^2 A}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"R_5 = \frac{2r\sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos B \cos C}{2 \sin A \sin B \sin C \cos B \cos C  + \sin B \sin C \cos B \cos C   -  \sin C \cos A \cos B \cos C - \sin C \cos B \cos^2 C}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"R_2 = \frac{2r\sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos B \cos C}{2 \sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos C  + \sin A \sin C \cos A \cos C   -  \sin C \cos A \cos B \cos C - \sin C \cos A \cos^2 C}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"R_4 = \frac{2r\sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos B \cos C}{2 \sin A \sin B \sin C \cos B \cos C  + \sin B \sin C \cos B \cos C   -  \sin B \cos A \cos B \cos C - \sin B \cos C \cos^2 B}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"R_6 = \frac{2r\sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos B \cos C}{2 \sin A \sin B \sin C \cos A \cos B  + \sin A \sin B \cos A \cos B   -  \sin A \cos A \cos B \cos C - \sin A \cos B \cos^2 A}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Careful examination shows that:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_3} + \frac{1}{R_5} = \frac{1}{R_2} + \frac{1}{R_4} + \frac{1}{R_6}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"only for acute isosceles (and equilateral) triangles, but "},{"type":"text","text":"not","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" for scalene triangles."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Finally, using the above equations, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\frac{1}{r_1} + \frac{1}{r_3} + \frac{1}{r_5}}{\frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_3} + \frac{1}{R_5}} = 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for equilateral triangles, but "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{\frac{1}{r_1} + \frac{1}{r_3} + \frac{1}{r_5}}{\frac{1}{R_1} + \frac{1}{R_3} + \frac{1}{R_5}} > 3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all other acute triangles.  In either case, the value of the integer part is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 12 Coins Puzzle
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the minimum number of tests on a balance scale to detect which one of 12 apparently equal coins differs slightly in weight from the others, without even knowing whether it is under- or overweight?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This problem was created by my father Howard Grossman and published Scripta Mathematica, Vol. XI, in 1945. It subsequently appeared in a Scientific American column authored by his friend Martin Gardner. The answer is 3. There are two ways of achieving this result: the direct way, and my Dad's way."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Number the coins from 1 to 12. The direct way is to start by weighing 1234 against 5678. If they balance, then weigh 19 against 10,11 and the final step is obvious. If 1234 does not balance 5678 then weigh 125 against 346. If the imbalance is in the same direction as the first weighing, weigh 1 against 2; in the opposite direction weigh 3 against 4.  But if 125 balances 346, then weigh 7 against 8."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"My Dad's solution is to use the ternary number system: The first weighing is represented as -1,0,+1, i.e., count -1 if the left pan goes up, +1 if the right pan goes up, and 0 if the pans balance; the second weighing is represented as -3, 0, +3; and the final weighing is represented as -9, 0, +9. So1=1+0+0; 2=-1+3+0; ...; 9=0+0+9; 10=1+0+9; 11=-1+3+9; and 12=0+3+9. A + sign means the coin goes on the left pan; a - sign means it goes on the right pan; and a 0 means that coin is not part of that weighing. This tells you how each coin should be used in each weighing, i.e., surprisingly the choice of coins for the later weighings doesn't depend at all on the earlier results. There is a slight hitch because in the second weighing you need to switch one coin from one pan to the other to have the same number of coins on both pans, and in the third weighing you need to switch 4 coins. So arbitrarily, change the numbering of coins 9, 10, 11, 12 to -9, -10, -11, and -12 and then if one of them is the answer, you need to reverse lighter and heavier."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/1I203RMJSt-centroidproblem1.png?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":"
Therefore, a minimum yellow area (and a minimum yellow to green ratio) must occur when the line through the centroid is parallel to the third side of the triangle."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since all centroids divide a median in a 2:1 proportion, a second parallel line can be drawn through the yellow section halfway up, and 1 of its 2 parts would be equal to 1 of the 4 parts along the parallel line through the centroid, and 1 of the 6 parts along the base.  The triangle can then be subdivided into congruent parallelograms using the base and the median though the base as guidelines (as pictured below), and the each of triangular parts can be matched with a matching triangular part through a 180° rotation to form more congruent parallelograms (also pictured below).
"},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/9ZRhZjOtEF-centroidproblem2.png?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":"
After all the transformations, there are 9 congruent parallelograms – 4 yellow and 5 green, for a ratio of 4/5 or 0.8."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

The lines move to adjust to that change, and as a result, keep the ratio.

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Looking at the first two samples, the ratios won't be changed if the top point is moved.  So the triangle may as well be equilateral.  As the line slants left or right towards a corner, the ratio approaches 1.  So the ratio is minimized when the line is horizontal."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The centroid is 1/3 of the way up.  So the horizontal line makes a yellow triangle 2/3 of size, or 4/9 the area of the whole triangle.  So the quadrilateral is the other 5/9.  The ratio between them is 4/5 = 0.8"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Actually this can be turned into a solution. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First notice that there is a linear area preserving transformation which sends your triangle to an equilateral triangle. To do so either use a ( infinite number of)  shear transformations or write out explicitly the constraints on  2x2 matrices with determinant one. (You can assume one vertex is at the origin, you have two constraints to bring the vertices where you want and one constraint for the fact the the determinant is one)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The symmetry argument is also mostly fine.
As the line which splits the triangle turns around the center there are moments where the triangle is split into two equal triangles. The ratio is then 1 which is the only possible [aboslute] maximum. Somewhere in between there has to be a [absolute] minimum (unless the ratio is constant, which the actual calculation show it isn't). 
Since there is a minimum, this has to happen when the drawn line is parallel to the bottom side (by symmetry)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the only catch is that there could be 2 [absolute] minima between the "obvious" maxima. I don't see an easy argument for that yet, but this seems very implausible.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}
